title: Nicole Fitzsimons killed in motorbike accident in Koh Samui Thailand
text:
735 shares 2

Nicole Fitzsimons was just 24 when she was tragically killed in a motorbike accident in Thailand.
She had a blossoming career as a sports journalist and was enjoying a beachside holiday with her boyfriend in Koh Samui to celebrate her first year working at the Footy Show.
Nicole and her boyfriend of six years Jamie Keith were on a motorbike on October 20 2012 waiting to turn into their hotel when another speeding rider tried to overtake them on the wrong side of the road and collided with their bike.
Nicole wasn't wearing a helmet and was knocked off the bike and killed.
Scroll down for video
Nicole Fitzsimons, 24, was killed in a motorbike accident while in Thailand with her boyfriend Jamie Keith
Nicole wasn't wearing a helmet and was knocked off the couple's bike and killed in Koh Samui in October 2012
Mr Keith survived, but was initially allegedly blamed for the crash by Thai police before CCTV footage proved he was not at fault.
Almost three years since Nicole's tragic death, her family is working to spread the message of travel safety at high schools around Australia to prevent other families from suffering a similar devastating loss.

Share this article Share After the accident, Nicole's parents Vince and Julie flew to Thailand to face the grim task of bringing their daughter's body home.
But they also had to deal with the fact that Thai authorities had confiscated Mr Keith's passport and allegedly asked him to sign a statement taking responsibility for the crash.
It took six days for police to return his passport so the family could fly home to Australia and give Nicole a proper memorial.
The 24-year-old had a blossoming career as a sports journalist and was enjoying a beachside holiday to celebrate her first year working at the Footy Show
Almost three years since Nicole's tragic death, her family is working to spread the message of travel safety
The couple were on their bike waiting to turn into their hotel when another speeding rider tried to overtake them on the wrong side of the road and collided with them
'I look back now and I'm not sure how we dealt with it,' Nicole's sister Kate Fitzsimons told Daily Mail Australia.
'We didn't really get a chance to grieve Nicole for that whole first week because we were dealing with the drama with the authorities.
'I don't think reality had sunk in that Nicole had passed away.'
In that time, they family's home in San Souci in Sydney's south was inundated with so many bunches of flowers their house 'looked like a florist'.
'The support was amazing but we thought we would love people to put their money towards something more meaningful than just flowers,' Kate said.
After the accident Nicole's parents Vince and Julie flew to Thailand to deal with the fact that Thai authorities had confiscated Mr Keith's passport and allegedly asked him to take responsibly for the crash
It took six days for police to return his passport so the family could fly home to Australia
So the family created a trust fund – the Nicole Fitzsimons Foundation – in her name.
Before Nicole decided to pursue a career in sports journalism she danced professionally at Tokyo Disney and the New Zealand Ballet, and part of the foundation is dedicated to giving small grants to budding sports people to help them further their careers.
Another part of the foundation is dedicated to travel safety campaigning, which Kate, 23, travels to schools around Australia to give talks to students.
'I've put together a 50-minute presentation that shares Nicole's story and some really practical travel advice,' she said.
'I've reached about 20,000 students so far.
'For Year 11 and 12 students the world's about to be at their feet, it's almost like a rite of passage to go overseas without Mum and Dad and do whatever they want.'
Nicole was an avid NRL fan and a supporter of the St George Illawarra Dragons
Her family created a trust fund – the Nicole Fitzsimons Foundation – in her name
Before Nicole decided to pursue a career in sports journalism she danced professionally at Tokyo Disney and the New Zealand Ballet
Kate said travellers often don't realise the danger they are putting themselves in by getting on a motorbike in a foreign country.
More than 100 Australians have died in Thailand since July last year, and about 150 were hospitalised.
'I've done a lot of research and Thailand has the second deadliest roads in the whole world,' she said.
'My sister didn't know she was jumping on the second deadliest roads in the world without a helmet.
'Nicole wasn't looking to take a risk, she just had that mentality a lot of us have on holidays that we'll be right.'
Another part of the foundation is dedicated to travel safety campaigning. Nicole's sister Kate (right) travels to schools around Australia to give talks to students
She has put together a 50-minute presentation that shares Nicole's story and practical travel advice
Kate said she had reached 20,000 students so far, and many have told her the presentation is 'life-changing'
Kate said that students often come up to her after her presentation to tell her it has been 'life-changing'.
'We have video footage of the crash, and playing that to the students really, really hits home how suddenly the unthinkable happens,' she said.
'I also remind everyone losing a loved one in a foreign country can be hard, it's a different culture, different rules, different punishments. Not everything's black and white over there.'
Kate said the family is still close to Mr Keith, who has since married a new partner.
'It's nice to say he's found new love, and his business is going really well,' she said.
Kate said the family is still close to Mr Keith (right), who has since married a new partner
Kate said she is determined to keep sharing Nicole's story, to honour her memory and to spread the importance of staying safe while travelling
'Jamie came up for her birthday this year and we spent it together and shared a cupcake – Nicole had a real sweet tooth.'
Kate said she is determined to keep sharing Nicole's story, to honour her memory and to spread the importance of staying safe while travelling.
'I knew she was destined to be famous. She would have gone far in the media,' she said.
'She was working at Channel Nine and had just finished her first year at the Footy Show and they absolutely loved her.
'That holiday was kind of the celebration of a great year, I remember when she booked it how excited she was.
'I can feel my heart heal with every presentation I give.'
